page.title: 12Peterborough Museum
page.content: I went to the museum one afternoon to speak to Martin Howe the curator about the Domesday Project. There I found a real character, a rugby player I suspect, whose knowledge of local history left me almost speechless. We stood there in the building which had been built in 1816 as a home for Squire Cook and was later used as a hospital and he spoke with a charming irreverance of the past populations of our city. In the Stone Age, it seems there was a thriving market economy centred at Castor with some 10,000 clay pots a week being manufactured and distributed. The Romans left behind them the makings of an impor- tant collection but perhaps the most unique is the collection of straw, woodwork, and paper models made by the Napoleonic prisoners-of-war during their up to 15 years imprisonment.
